div.head: Introduction
div.p:
On January 1st, 1594 Marenzio signed the dedication of his Sesto libro de madrigali a cinque voci to Cinzio Aldobrandini Passeri (1551–1610), nephew of Pope Clement VIII and recently appointed cardinal. Aldobrandini was a distinguished patron of artists and poets, famously of Torquato Tasso; Battista Guarini, G. Bardi and Angelo Grillo, among others, were part of his patronage network.
See Elena Fasano Guarini, “Aldobrandini (Passeri), Cinzio”, in Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani, vol. 2 (Rome: Istituto della Enciclopedia italiana, 1960; on line at http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/cinzio-aldobrandini_(Dizionario-Biografico)/, accessed August 25, 2014); Marco Bizzarini, Luca Marenzio: The Career of a Musician Between the Renaissance and the Counter-Reformation, trans. James Chater (Aldershot, Hants, England; Burlington, VT: Ashgate, 2003), 197–199. The dedication, entirely constructed from genre-specific topoi and clichés, does not shed any further light on the circumstances of the composition and of the arrangement for publication. As is well known, after the death of his former patron Cardinal Luigi d’Este in 1586, Marenzio had served Ferdinando de’ Medici in Rome and in Florence (1587–1589 or 1590), then, back in Rome, had maintained multiple patronage connections, notably with Virginio Orsini (from 1589/90) and with Aldobrandini (probably from 1593).
For a recent and documented précis, see Paolo Fabbri, “Marenzio, Luca” in Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani, vol. 70 (Rome: Istituto della Enciclopedia italiana, 2007; on line at http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/luca-marenzio_(Dizionario-Biografico)/, accessed August 25, 2014). Meanwhile, his publication rhythm had considerably slowed down, compared to the years 1580 to 1587: the period 1588–1593 had seen only the publication of the Book for 4, 5, and 6 voices (1588) and of Book V a 6 (1591).

As if marking the end of this transitional phase or, rather, the beginning of a new chapter in Marenzio’s career, Book VI a 5 is characterized by a distinct change in the choice of texts, by a subtle montage, and by a noticeable stylistic shift.

The most innovative feature regards, however, Guarini: not so much for the presence and number of his texts (Marenzio had repeatedly set Guarini’s poetry since his first madrigal book, Book I a 5 of 1580), as for their provenance from a work of crucial importance in late sixteenth-century culture, Il pastor fido. While de Monte and Monteverdi published Pastor fido settings before Marenzio,
De Monte in his Book XIV a 5 (1590) and Monteverdi in his III a 5 (1592), one setting each: see James Chater, “Fonti poetiche per i madrigali di Luca Marenzio,” Rivista italiana di musicologia 13, no. 1 (1978), 60–103: 71–72. the latter was, in the words of Marco Bizzarini, “the first of the leading madrigalists to set passages from Guarini’s drama in more than a sporadic way”.
Bizzarini, Luca Marenzio, 257. The present book and the following one in the five-voice series (VII a 5, 1595) “have for Il pastor fido a pioneering importance”.
Ibid. While the possibility of a direct contact between Marenzio and Guarini remains an undocumented speculation, and the circles of Aldobrandini and Cardinal Montalto might have played an instrumental role,
See again Bizzarini, Luca Marenzio, 293. it has recently been suggested that Cardinal Scipione Gonzaga (1542–1593) could have brought Il pastor fido to Marenzio’s attention “as a promising source of madrigal texts”.
See Seth J. Coluzzi, “‘Tirsi mio, caro Tirsi’: Il pastor fido and the Roman Madrigal, in Perspectives on Luca Marenzio’s Secular Music, 51–74: 51–53 Be it as it may, Marenzio’s settings probably accompanied and fuelled the discussion about Guarini’s controversial play in Cardinal Aldobrandini’s ridotto (and elsewhere, after the publication), and offered a sort of alternative realization of some passages, as if on the virtual, polyphonic stage of the madrigal.
See Coluzzi, “‘Tirsi mio, caro Tirsi’”, 54–55.

As many scholars have noticed,
See for instance Chater, “Fonti poetiche per i madrigali di Luca Marenzio,” 76–77. some of the names occurring in the texts set by Marenzio have been systematically altered. In no. 2, Clori nel mio partire, no. 10, Or chi, Clori beata, no. 12, Clori mia, Clori dolce, oh sempre nuovo, and no. 15, “Rimanti in pace”, a la dolente e bella, the original “Flora”, “Filli”, or “Fillida” have been substituted by “Clori”/“Cloride”, while the first line in the Pastor fido passage set as no. 11, Deh, Tirsi, Tirsi, anima mia, perdona, originally sounded “E tu, Mirtillo, anima mia, perdona”.
For full details and literature, see the notes to the individual texts in “The poetic texts: edition and critical report”. The two names also occur in nos. 6, Stillò l’anima in pianto (Tirsi and Clori), 16, Ecco Maggio seren, chi l’ha vestito (Clori, this time together with Filli), and 17, Cantiam la bella Clori (Clori only). Thus, Giuseppe Gerbino speaks of a “subtle but unmistakable narrative thread” that underlies the book: “the story of Tirsi and Clori”.
Giuseppe Gerbino, “Marenzio and the Shepherds of the Tiber Valley”, in Perspectives on Luca Marenzio’s Secular Music, 265–282: 265.

Noticing that Tirsi was the pseudonym used by Virginio Orsini in his capacity as “prince” of the pastoral society known as “pastori della valle tiberina” (shepherds of the Tiber valley), James Chater has hypothesized that Tirsi and Clori should be identified as Virginio and his wife, Flavia Peretti.
Chater, “Fonti poetiche per i madrigali di Luca Marenzio,” 77. In his recent and well-documented reassessment of the question, Giuseppe Gerbino has found “no evidence either against or in support of Chater’s hypothesis”, and incidentally suggested that Clori could have been “a singer connected with the Orsini family”: see Gerbino, “Marenzio and the Shepherds of the Tiber Valley”, 266 and 277. In this perspective, the final piece (no. 17, Cantiam la bella Clori), whose epithalamic character has often been pointed out, should be interpreted as a nuptial homage to Flavia, whom Virginio had married in 1589. But besides the fact that Marenzio had already included a tribute to the pair in Book V a 6 in 1591,
Dedicated to the same Virginio Orsini: see Paolo Cecchi, “List of Secular and Devotional Compositions by Luca Marenzio”, in Perspectives on Luca Marenzio’s Secular Music, 465–522: 501–502. a new piece of information further complicates the matter.

In 1595, just one year after the publication of our book, Marenzio dedicated his Book VI a 6 to Margherita Gonzaga (1564–1618); the opening piece, Lucida perla a cui fu conca il cielo, sets the final part (lines 73–85) of a pastoral dialogue written by Guarini in 1579 to celebrate the wedding between Margherita and Duke Alfonso II d’Este, Dimmi, gentil pastore (but often printed under the name of Tasso in contemporary sources).
See Angelo Solerti, Le rime di Torquato Tasso, I: Bibliografia (Bologna: Romagnoli-Dall’Acqua, 1898), 502–503. All this is well-known, at least since Chater’s seminal article of 1978:
See Chater, “Fonti poetiche per i madrigali di Luca Marenzio,” 78. what seems to have gone unnoticed so far is that the final piece of our book, Cantiam la bella Clori, is nothing but an adaptation from the immediately previous section of the same dialogue by Guarini (lines 60–72). Once again, the name Clori is purposely inserted a posteriori in the text (here, instead of “Dea” and “Reina”).
See the relevant entry in “The poetic texts: edition and critical report” for a full comparison of the two texts.

As a result of this discovery, we have one more text by (in fact, adapted from) Guarini in Book VI a 5, and more doubts about the identity of Clori and the meaning of the whole Tirsi & Clori operation. Is this an old or a new piece? Did Marenzio set the excerpt from Guarini’s dialogue back in 1579, for Margherita’s wedding, and publish it, in a revised version, fifteen years later? Were the textual changes meant to severe the link with the 1579 event, and with Margherita, in order to make possible a reuse of the piece on a different occasion and for a different purpose? Then, why to reaffirm the original connection the following year, dedicating (or re-dedicating) the ‘sequel’ piece Lucida perla a cui fu conca il cielo to the initial dedicatee? Delicate issues of compositional chronology are at stake,
In the introduction to her edition of Book VI a 6, Patricia Myers suggested to date Lucida perla back to 1579: see Luca Marenzio, The Secular Works. 6: Il sesto libro de’ madrigali a sei voci (1595), ed. by Patricia Myers (New York: The Broude Trust, 1983). Chater, in his review of the edition (JAMS 38, no. 2 [1985], 376–385), essentially accepted Myers’ view on this regard, but provided that one postulated substantial revisions by Marenzio before the 1595 publication. In our case, given the full-sounding but straightforward chordal nature of Cantiam la bella Clori and the fact that some relatively advanced details of the polychoral writing could easily be the fruit of a 1590s’ revision, it seems hard to draw definitive conclusions based on stylistic analysis. and further research is needed to answer, or at least to reframe, these questions.

Returning to Tirsi and Clori, and to their role within the structure of Book VI a 5, Mauro Calcagno has recently proposed to read the entire book as a coherent narrative, with three alternating ‘voices’ (Tirsi, Clori, and the Narrator) and four sections: the “separation between the lovers” (nos. 1–9), is followed by a phase of “rapprochement and intimacy” (nos. 10–13), then by “death” (nos. 14–15), and by the “final attainment of love” (nos. 16–17).
Mauro Calcagno, From Madrigal to Opera Monteverdi’s Staging of the Self (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012), 172–174. As further pointed out by Calcagno, this “script” seems to interact with other ordering criteria: the madrigals of the first “section”, for instance, are all written in low clefs (c1c3c4c4f4), but other, essentially musical, structuring principles are clearly at work (see Table 2).

All the scholars who have studied this book, at least since Alfred Einstein, have underscored the stylistic shift from Marenzio’s previous collections.
See the discussion and the literature quoted in Steven Ledbetter, et al. “Marenzio, Luca.” Grove Music Online. Oxford Music Online. Oxford University Press, accessed August 25, 2014, http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/40081; Bizzarini, Luca Marenzio, 293–295; and Piero Gargiulo, “Quella ‘melodia soavissima’. Perle marenziane nel Sesto libro a cinque (1594)”, in Miscellanea marenziana, ed. by Maria Teresa Rosa Barezzani and Antonio Delfino, «Diverse voci...» 9 (Pisa: Edizioni ETS, 2007), 277–290. In line with the innovative poetic choices discussed above, Marenzio developed a new lyric-declamatory style that went beyond the somehow fragmented aesthetic of madrigalism and allowed him to convey in a different, more dramatic way the intense expressivity of the texts. In all the pieces but no. 8 a single soprano is opposed to four lower voices (generally ATTB), often to achieve a more direct association with the ‘acting’ persona it musically represents.
Marenzio never wrote a “monody”: John Walter Hill has pointed out, however, that no. 4, Anima cruda sì, ma però bella, has significant melodic connections with an anonymous monodic piece preserved in manuscript I-Bc Q.140, which could have been used as a model by Marenzio; see John Walter Hill, Roman Monody, Cantata, and Opera from the Circles Around Cardinal Montalto (Oxford; New York: Clarendon Press ; Oxford University Press, 1997)I, 247–255; Bizzarini, Luca Marenzio, 191–192 questions this interpretation. As penetratingly remarked by Bizzarini, however, the book does not have a “unified character”, but is rather inspired by a “subtly pluralistic aesthetic”:
Bizzarini, Luca Marenzio, 294. the touching monologues and laments on texts by Guarini and Tasso (which Einstein called “actual scenes”)
The Italian Madrigal, trans. A.H. Krappe, R.H. Sessions, and O. Strunk, vol. 2 (Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1949), 669. alternate with lighter pieces (no. 10, with multi-voice ornamental flourishes and a dialogic structure; no. 16, with dance-like triple time sections; and the celebratory no. 17 for two choirs);
For the presence of bichoral works as concluding pieces in several of Marenzio’s madrigal books, see Bizzarini, Luca Marenzio, 308. other compositions experiment with daring chromaticisms and harmonic progressions (e.g., no. 5), echo certain features of contemporary Roman madrigals (no. 13), or even display an arioso character (no. 9).

Compared to some of the most famous books by Marenzio, such as the first and the last in the series a 5, Book VI has apparently had a modest success:
See Gargiulo, “Quella ‘melodia soavissima’”, 281–282. republished in its entirety (with the exception of no. 17) in the comprehensive collections of Marenzio’s five-voice madrigals issued by Kauffmann in Nuremberg (1601) and by the Phalèse firm in Antwerp (1609 and 1632),
See “Description of the sources and consulted copies”. it has had otherwise no reprints in anthologies. Madrigal no. 13, Mentre qual viva pietra, formed the basis for one of Girolamo Cavaglieri’s contrafacta
In RISM 16168: see the “Critical report”. and, according to Chater,
See James Chater, Luca Marenzio and the Italian Madrigal, 1577–1593 (Ann Arbor, Mich.: UMI, 1981), Appendix II, 208. worked as a model for a Magnificat a 6 by Michael Praetorius.
A Missa Mentre qual viva pietra by G. Belli (Missae sacrae, 1608) is probably based on the same madrigal, given that no other setting of this text is known, but this information needs to be verified. No. 3, Donna de l’alma mia, de la mia vita, was intabulated for the lute by Joachim van den Hove in his Delitiae mvsicae.
RISM 161218: see the “Critical report”. A handful of pieces were copied in English manuscripts
See Paolo Cecchi, “‘Delicious air and sweet invention’: The Circulation and Consumption of Marenzio’s Secular Music in England (c. 1588–1640)”, in Perspectives on Luca Marenzio’s Secular Music, 283–370: 347–350. (but a comprehensive mapping of Marenzio’s presence in manuscript sources is still to be done).

On the other hand, Severo Bonini, in his Discorsi e regole (c. 1653), singles out this book as an example of Marenzio’s proficiency in what he calls “terzo ordine” and de facto corresponds to Monteverdi’s seconda pratica.
See Gargiulo, “Quella ‘melodia soavissima’”, 282–283. Gargiulo reads Bonini’s passage as a reference to no. 1, S’io parto, i’ moro, e pur partir conviene, only, but in my opinion Bonini’s phrasing refers to the whole book, identified through the opening piece, as it happens elsewhere in his text. Furthermore, a systematic investigation about the texts set by Marenzio in Book VI a 5 and their concordances in other music collections indirectly attests to a favorable reception of the book: Marenzio was often the first to choose texts which later became popular among madrigalists (a clear example is no. 5, Udite lagrimosi).

The princeps of the book, issued by Angelo Gardano in Venice in 1594,
See “Description of the sources and consulted copies”. is a remarkably accurate and correct edition, and the extant re-editions of 1603 and 1614 are also substantially reliable. The 1614 re-edition may derive directly from the princeps, based on the variants and on details of the mise-en-page and of ‘calibration’.
The 1614 print is in vertical format, while the princeps is in oblong format: often, however, the content of the first two staves of the 1614 page exactly corresponds to that of the first staff in the princeps (in other cases, three staves of 1614 accommodate the content of two staves of the princeps). For the term ‘calibration’ to indicate the operations of organizing the page layout and calculating the distribution of the music in the book, see Laurent Pugin, “Music Printers at Work: Marenzio’s Madrigali a quattro voci, libro primo”, in Perspectives on Luca Marenzio’s Secular Music, 409–430: 411. Pending a systematic recognition of the extant copies of the princeps with Aruspix,
See Pugin, “Music Printers at Work”, 415–417. I have been able to detect only two cases of stop-press correction. One occurs on the dedication page of the Basso partbook: while the copy held at Modena, Biblioteca Estense Universitaria (I-MOe), has a misprint in the signature: “Luca Marenzo” (!), all the other consulted copies have the correct reading. The other case regards page 8 in the Tenore partbook (madrigal no. 8, Ben ho del caro oggetto i sensi privi): in the copies held in Berkeley, Brussels, and London, the d3 at m. 16 is a semiminima instead of a minima; the other consulted copies have the correct reading.
